original_data.question:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size have changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). He is at the 5th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Na+ 145 mEq/L
K+ 4.1 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
HCO3- 25 mEq/L
Ca2+ 9.4 mg/dL
Glucose 110 mg/dL
Thyroid-stimulating hormone 0.3 μU/mL
Thyroxine 3.9 μg/dL
Insulin-like growth factor 1 24 ng/mL (N=61–356 ng/mL)
Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 2.1 mcg/mL (N=1.6–6.5 μg/mL)
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?"

model_response: The patient has hypopituitarism with short stature, signs of diabetes insipidus, and precocious puberty. The low serum sodium concentration and high urine sodium concentration are consistent with diabetes insipidus. The low serum potassium concentration may be secondary to dehydration. The low serum calcium concentration may be secondary to hypoparathyroidism. The low serum glucose concentration may be secondary to hypoglycemia. The low serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration is consistent with primary hypothyroidism. The low serum T4 concentration is consistent with central hypothyroidism. The low serum growth hormone concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low insulin-like growth factor 1 concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low serum testosterone concentration is consistent with precocious puberty. The low serum FSH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum LH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum prolactin concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum TSH concentration is consistent with primary hypothyroidism. The low serum T4 concentration is consistent with central hypothyroidism. The low serum growth hormone concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low insulin-like growth factor 1 concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low serum testosterone concentration is consistent with precocious puberty. The low serum FSH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum LH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum T4 concentration is consistent with central hypothyroidism. The low serum growth hormone concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low serum FSH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum LH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum prolactin concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum TSH concentration is consistent with primary hypothyroidism. The low serum T4 concentration is consistent with central hypothyroidism. The low serum growth hormone concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low serum T4 concentration is consistent with central hypothyroidism. The low serum growth hormone concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low insulin-like growth factor 1 concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 concentration is consistent with growth hormone deficiency. The low serum testosterone concentration is consistent with precocious puberty. The low serum FSH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum LH concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum prolactin concentration is consistent with primary hypogonadism. The low serum TSH concentration is consistent with primary hypothyroidism. question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
A genetic or pathological condition that is characterized by short stature and undersize. Abnormal skeletal growth usually results in an adult who is significantly below the average height.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Involuntary erection or bristling of hairs.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
The time in every 24 hour period when it is dark.
Coming at short intervals or in great quantities.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

A short-acting beta-2 adrenergic agonist that is primarily used as a bronchodilator agent to treat ASTHMA. Albuterol is prepared as a racemic mixture of R(-) and S(+) stereoisomers. The stereospecific preparation of R(-) isomer of albuterol is referred to as levalbuterol.

A group of polycyclic compounds closely related biochemically to TERPENES. They include cholesterol, numerous hormones, precursors of certain vitamins, bile acids, alcohols (STEROLS), and certain natural drugs and poisons. Steroids have a common nucleus, a fused, reduced 17-carbon atom ring system, cyclopentanoperhydrophenanthrene. Most steroids also have two methyl groups and an aliphatic side-chain attached to the nucleus. (From Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary, 11th ed)
Female parents, human or animal.
An autoimmune disorder caused by the production of autoantibodies against thyroid tissue. There is progressive destruction of the thyroid follicles leading to hypothyroidism.

A period in the human life in which the development of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal system takes place and reaches full maturity. The onset of synchronized endocrine events in puberty lead to the capacity for reproduction (FERTILITY), development of secondary SEX CHARACTERISTICS, and other changes seen in ADOLESCENT DEVELOPMENT.
Milk that is produced by HUMAN MAMMARY GLANDS.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
Male parents, human or animal.
Any of the 99 numbered points that divide an ordered set of scores into 100 parts each of which contains one-hundredth of the total.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
Any of the 99 numbered points that divide an ordered set of scores into 100 parts each of which contains one-hundredth of the total.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
The external and internal organs involved in the functions of REPRODUCTION.
A bone that forms the lower and anterior part of each side of the hip bone.

A filament-like structure consisting of a shaft which projects to the surface of the SKIN from a root which is softer than the shaft and lodges in the cavity of a HAIR FOLLICLE. It is found on most surfaces of the body.

A scale of physical development in children, adolescents and adults based on external primary and secondary sex characteristics, such as the size of the breasts, genitalia, and development of pubic hair.
Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.
Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella. [HPO:probinson]
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

A glycoprotein hormone secreted by the adenohypophysis (PITUITARY GLAND, ANTERIOR). Thyrotropin stimulates THYROID GLAND by increasing the iodide transport, synthesis and release of thyroid hormones (THYROXINE and TRIIODOTHYRONINE). Thyrotropin consists of two noncovalently linked subunits, alpha and beta. Within a species, the alpha subunit is common in the pituitary glycoprotein hormones (TSH; LUTEINIZING HORMONE and FSH), but the beta subunit is unique and confers its biological specificity.

The major hormone derived from the thyroid gland. Thyroxine is synthesized via the iodination of tyrosines (MONOIODOTYROSINE) and the coupling of iodotyrosines (DIIODOTYROSINE) in the THYROGLOBULIN. Thyroxine is released from thyroglobulin by proteolysis and secreted into the blood. Thyroxine is peripherally deiodinated to form TRIIODOTHYRONINE which exerts a broad spectrum of stimulatory effects on cell metabolism.

Insulin-like polypeptides made by the liver and some fibroblasts and released into the blood when stimulated by SOMATOTROPIN. They cause sulfate incorporation into collagen, RNA, and DNA synthesis, which are prerequisites to cell division and growth of the organism.
A family of soluble proteins that bind insulin-like growth factors and modulate their biological actions at the cellular level. (Int J Gynaecol Obstet 1992;39(1):3-9)

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
